column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Connes	Alain Connes (born 1 April 1947) is a French mathematician
column2: currently Professor at the Collège de France
column4: The Ohio State University and Vanderbilt University.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Connes	Work
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Connes	Alain Connes is one of the leading specialists on operator algebras.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Connes	In his early work on von Neumann algebras in the 1970s
column2: he succeeded in obtaining the almost complete classification of injective factors.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Connes	Following this he made contributions in operator K-theory and index theory
column2: which culminated in the

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Connes	Baum-Connes conjecture.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Connes	He also introduced cyclic cohomology in the early 1980s as a first step in the study of noncommutative differential geometry.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Connes	Connes has applied his work in areas of mathematics and theoretical physics
column2: including number theory

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Connes	Awards and honours
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Connes	Connes was awarded the Fields Medal in 1982
column2: the Crafoord Prize in 2001 and the gold medal of the CNRS in 2004.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alain_Connes	He is a member of the French Academy of Sciences and several foreign academies and societies
column2: including the Danish Academy of Sciences
column5: and US National Academy of Sciences.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	An astronomer is a scientist who studies celestial bodies such as planets
column2: stars and galaxies.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	Historically
column2: astronomy was more concerned with the classification and description of phenomena in the sky
column3: while astrophysics attempted to explain these phenomena and the differences between them using physical laws.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	Today
column2: that distinction has mostly disappeared and the terms " astronomer " and " astrophysicist " are interchangeable.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	Professional astronomers are highly educated individuals who typically have a PhD in physics or astronomy and are employed by research institutions or universities.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	They spend the majority of their time working on research
column2: although they quite often have other duties such as teaching
column4: or aiding in the operation of an observatory.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	The number of professional astronomers in the United States is actually quite small.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	The American Astronomical Society
column2: which is the major organization of professional astronomers in North America

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	This number includes scientists from other fields such as physics
column2: geology
column4: whose research interests are closely related to astronomy.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	The International Astronomical Union comprises almost 10
column2: 145 members from 70 different countries who are involved in astronomical research at the PhD level and beyond.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	While the number of professional astronomers worldwide is not much larger than the population of a small town
column2: there is a huge community of amateur astronomers.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	Most cities have amateur astronomy clubs that meet on a regular basis and often host star parties in their communities.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	The Astronomical Society of the Pacific is the largest general astronomical society in the world
column2: comprising both professional and amateur astronomers as well as educators from 70 different nations.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	Like any hobby
column2: most people who think of themselves as amateur astronomers may devote a few hours a month to stargazing and reading the latest developments in research.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	However
column2: amateurs span the range from so-called " armchair astronomers " to the very ambitious
column3: who own science-grade telescopes and instruments with which they are able to make their own discoveries and assist professional astronomers in research.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	Modern astronomers
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	Contrary to the classical image of an old astronomer peering through a telescope through the dark hours of the night
column2: it is very rare for a modern professional astronomer to use an eyepiece on a larger telescope.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	It is far more common to use a charge-coupled device camera to record a long
column2: deep exposure
column3: allowing a more sensitive image to be created because the light is added over time.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	Before CCDs
column2: photographic plates were a common method of observation.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	Modern astronomers spend relatively little time at telescopes-most spend a few weeks per year observing
column2: and the rest of their time reducing the data (changing it from raw data to processed images) and analyzing it.

column1: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	Many astronomers work entirely from astronomical survey or space observatory data.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronomer	Others work with radio telescopes like the Very Large Array
column2: which is entirely automated
column3: although it is maintained by telescope operators.
